content.description: Climb the thin crack until It leans left and ends. Here, the nature of the route changes from moderate crack climbing to technical face climbing on dubiously attached, crimpy holds. Two bolts protect this face. A short but worthwhile climb.
content.protection: Single rack to 3”. Two lead bolts above the crack lead to a two-bolt anchor, which was recently equipped with rap rings thanks to the Bower Climbing Coalition. This anchor isn't accessible from above without rapping in from a gear anchor.
content.location: This route is on a formation called “The Island” which is approximately 10 yards Southeast of the Bird Watching Boulder. Currently, this is the only lead route on The Island. The route faces West and follows a variable thin crack that arches up and left until it pinches off.

content.description:
Climb the wide flaring crack that is a bit overhanging at the beginning.

Climb this crack to the anchors of The Early Bird.

Smile, because you got another use out of your super huge cams that cost so much!

Snicker, because you left the cams in the pack, and clipped the bolts from The Early Bird instead!
content.protection:
Bring your Big Bros,

or use Early Birds' 6 bolts and bolted anchors.
content.location:
Look for a wide crack that splits the North side of the boulder, to the right of the route The Vulture.

The routes The Early Bird and The Worm are located here and both routes share the same bolts and anchors.

While climbing The Worm, stay in the crack to the Right of the bolts.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb North side.

content.description:
This route shares the bolts and anchors with the route The Worm.

Start just to the left of the off-width crack and climb the face, staying to the left of the bolt line untill you get to the last few moves of the route, where you may move slightly right to the anchors.
content.location:
Look for a wide crack that splits the North side of the boulder, to the right of the route The Vulture.

The routes The Early Bird and The Worm are located here and both routes share the same bolts and anchors.

While climbing The Early Bird, stay to the left of the bolts for a completely distinct route than The Worm.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb North side.

content.description:
Starting in the vertical seam, grunt your way up this one and try not to loose a finger in the tight crack... The vultures will be circling, hoping for a treat.

Follow the seam to a ledge, from here the route gets juggy and quite fun. The crux is back in the crack, where it probably left an imprint in your finger.
content.location:
You will find The Vulture on the East side of the Boulder, one route to the right of No Egrets, where the face becomes less overhanging.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb the North side.

content.description: Starting out a bit overhanging, pulling thru good holds to the face, you may find the beginning of this route to be a bit cruxy, but 5.7 seems to be a popular consensus rating. Once on the vertical face continue up thru many large "turkey heads" (O.K. chicken heads, but this route was bolted and got it's First Ascent on Thanksgiving Day, 1999).  The last couple moves are a bit smaller and finish the route off at a consistent grade.
content.location:
One route to the right of Spring Kitten, this is the very featured line in the middle of the South face. The start is located below a small roof heading up out onto a vertical face.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb the North side.

content.description: Classic slab moves for the first half of this route take you to a huge rest hold at the beginning of the overhang.  From the jug, head up to a match on the heuco, and then start firing up pockets thru the continuously overhanging face to the last moves, where the big holds run out, but the angle stays steep.
content.location: This route is on the South end of the West face. The start is on the slab directly below the large heuco, which is halfway up the face where the slab becomes an overhang.

content.description: A "harder than it looks" left leaning crack that encounters a crux down low at the small overhang.  Eases up from here to the top.
content.protection:
Besides a standard selection of pro, it is helpful, but not necessary to have a larger camming unit for protecting the crux.

Belay the second via a traditional anchor from inside a pod at the top of the boulder.
content.location:
One route to the right of Subconscious Bird Watcher. Starts at the base of the large crack on the South Face.

Head off the North side where there is a 5.3 downclimb, or you could lower off the anchors of Turkey Heads.

content.description: Start on the vertical/slabby face through good holds to the base of the overhang. Set up, make the clip, and dyno big to the left, aiming for a pocket on the arete. This hold is hard to see, and thus hard to stick, hence the name Snipe Hunt (after a few fruitless dynos you may start to wonder if you are trying to find a pocket that is not there.) Continue up the arete for a couple moves and then move slightly right as you head for the anchors. The crux is not the dyno, but while heading from the arete to the face on the right after the dyno.  Hang on and don't run out of ammo before the hunt is over!
content.location:
This route is on the West side of the boulder and is located on the right side of the prow next to the mossy gully, one route to the left of Subconscious Birdwatcher.

It is recommended to lower off from the anchors.

content.description:
This route has not seen many ascents, and appears to be significantly harder than the originally suggested 5.9.

The first half is 5.9, and then the last bolts is nails.
content.protection: Three bolts to lower off anchor. The anchor can be hard to approach for TR.
content.location: You can find this "Little Chicken" on the far West side of the boulder, to the left, and on the other side of the mossy gully, of The Snipe Hunt.

content.description: A very dynamic start with fun pumpy moves.  Starting on the overhanging face and pulling thru unique, challenging sequences to reach a ledge.  From here, the route heads up the South East prow to a lieback section and then to the top of the boulder.
content.location:
Located just to the right of the SE corner, one route right of Flipping The Bird, at the base of the beautiful overhanging face.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb the North side.

content.description:
A very tricky and crimpy start thru a pumpy overhanging section which then heads slightly left on the steep face above.  Crux is down low.

(This route was bolted on Thanksgiving Day, 2000, and the name originated from the whole cooking the turkey idea. I didn't get the First Ascent until Spring 2001 after quite a few tries, so the name kinda took on a slightly different meaning.)
content.location:
One route to the right of Falcor, starting at the base of the overhang just to the left of the South East corner.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb the North side.

content.description: A fun route with the crux down low, pulling the final move of the overhanging section.  From here it's vertical with good edges.  Named for the funky bird/dog critter in the movie "Never Ending Story".
content.location:
One route to the right of Turkey Heads. Route starts at the left side of the overhanging section and pulls thru the overhang to the steep face above.

Lower off anchors, or hike off/downclimb North side.
